metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Hai River Basin (Guantao site-automatic weather station) (2008-2010)
metadata.description:
The data set contains observations from the automatic weather station as of 31 December 2010 as of 1 solstice January 2008.The site is located in hezhai village, guantao county, hebei province.The latitude and longitude of the observation point is 115.1274E, 36.5150N, and the altitude is 30m.

The acquisition frequency of the automatic weather station is 10s, and the output of 10min is once.The observation factors include air temperature and relative humidity (12.5m), and the direction is due north.Wind speed (12.7m), wind direction (12.7m), heading due north;Air pressure (installed in waterproof box);Rainfall (16m);Net radiation/four-component radiation (15.6m), facing due south;Infrared surface temperature (15.7m), the arm is facing south, the probe is facing vertically downward;The soil temperature and humidity probe was buried 2m south of the meteorological tower. The buried depth of the soil temperature probe was 0cm, 2cm, 5cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 60cm, 80cm and 100cm. The buried depth of the soil moisture sensor was 2cm, 5cm, 10cm, 10cm, 10cm, 10cm, 20cm, 60cm, 80cm and 100cm.Two soil hot plates (2) were buried 2cm underground, one under the vegetation and the other between the trees.Processing and quality control of observation data :(1) ensure 144 data per day (every 10min). If data is missing, it will be marked by -6999;(2) eliminate the moments with duplicate records;(3) data that is obviously beyond the physical meaning or the range of the instrument is deleted;(4) the format of date and time is unified, and the date and time are in the same column.For example, the time is: June 10, 2010 at 10:30.

Data released by the automatic weather station include:Date/Time, air temperature and humidity observation (ta_12.5m, rh_12.5m) (℃, %), wind speed (ws_12.7m) (m/s), wind direction (wd_12.7m) (°), pressure (Press) (hpa), precipitation (Rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, UR, DLR_Cor, ULR_Cor, Rn) (W/m2), surface radiation temperature (IRT_1, IRT_2) (℃),Soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2) (W/m2), multi-layer soil moisture (Ms_2cm, Ms_5cm, Ms_10cm, Ms_20cm, Ms_40cm, Ms_60cm, Ms_100cm) (%) and multi-layer soil temperature (Ts_0cm, Ts_2cm, Ts_5cm, Ts_10cm, Ts_20cm, Ts_40cm, Ts_60cm, Ts_80cm, Ts_100cm) (℃).

Please refer to Jia et al,(2012) for information of observation test or site, and Liu et al,(2013) for data processing.

background: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. Originally, z0m is defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. According to numerous observations, the variation range of z0m over different surfaces is large, from an order of 1.0 m over urban areas and mountainous areas, to an order of 0.1 mm or even 0.01 mm over smooth water body surfaces, ice and snow surfaces. The traditional way to calculate z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements. In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, it is difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations. Former researchers have proposed some parameterizations between the aerodynamic roughness length and the land surface properties [e.g., vegetation height, leaf area index (LAI), etc.], since wind turbulence is controlled by the structure and spacing of roughness elements (plants and other obstacles) on the land surface, and z0m describes the roughness characteristics of a surface.
research objective: Based on the data of the Xiaotangshan Experiment (Changping District of Beijing, China), which was conducted in 2002, 2004, and 2005 respectively, the objectives of this paper are: (1) to calculate z0m over different surfaces and analyze the directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model; (2) to relate the estimated z0m over heterogeneous surfaces to roughness element characteristic factors, and present a heuristic parameterization of z0m as a reference for model parameterizations.
challenges: More data is needed for further discussions.
methods: This paper calculates z0m over several land surfaces, with 3 years of experimental data from Xiaotangshan. Individual z0m over each surface component (patch) is calculated firstly with the characteristic parameters of the roughness elements (vegetation height, leaf area index, etc.), then z0m over the whole experimental field is aggregated, using the footprint weighting method.
dataset: This experiment was carried out at the Xiaotangshan Experimental Station for Precision Agriculture (40°10′41′′N, 116°26′52′′E, 35 m above sea level) in Beijing. The observation period in 2002 was from 26 March to 23 April and the land cover was bare soil. In 2004, the experiment was carried out from 30 May to 7 July. In the southern sub-plot field, the land cover was bare soil between 30 May and 11 June, while the maize plants started emerging around 12 June. In 2005, the experiment was from 1 May to 10 June and the experimental layout was almost the same as that in 2004.
findings: The results show that z0m is direction-dependent, mainly due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions.

background: Sensible and latent heat fluxes are important indicators reflecting the intensity of heat and water vapor exchange between the land and atmosphere, influencing the energy balance between them, providing material, dynamic, and thermal sources for weather systems of different scales, and affecting the water cycle process between the land and atmosphere. Currently, there are many traditional methods for observing surface fluxes, such as the Eddy-Covariance system (EC), Bowen ratio-energy balance system, and aerodynamic methods. Among these, the Eddy-Covariance system is internationally recognized as the most reliable method for observing surface fluxes; however, its observation scale is relatively small, with spatial representativeness only on the order of tens to hundreds of meters. The Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS), compared to traditional Eddy-Covariance systems, can obtain average sensible heat fluxes at a regional scale (from hundreds of meters to several kilometers). Since the observation scale of LAS can better match the pixel scale of satellite imagery and the grid scale of numerical weather prediction and climate models, the observations from LAS can serve as ground truth for the pixel/grid scale of remote sensing estimation models, numerical weather prediction models, and climate models, thereby optimizing and validating these models. The observation principle of LAS is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST), which, combined with the observed atmospheric refractive index structure parameter C2n and related meteorological data, utilizes the stability universal function fT related to the temperature structure parameter C2T to obtain the regional average sensible heat flux at the surface.
research objective: Using the LAS-related data from Guantao Station (January to December 2009) and Arou Station (January to June and October to November), the applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in LAS observations was analyzed, and a quantitative assessment method for the applicability of MOST was explored.
challenges: Due to the influence of underlying surface cover types, flatness, water-thermal conditions, and weather conditions, it is difficult to achieve the ideal assumption of uniformity in practice. Currently, domestic research on atmospheric similarity theory mainly focuses on the similarity relationships of wind, temperature profiles, and turbulence variance. However, there is relatively little research on the similarity between temperature structure parameters and turbulence characteristics in scintillation methods.
methods: Before analyzing the applicability of the MOST theory to LAS data, preliminary processing of EC and LAS data is conducted. LAS, EC, and AWS data from the Guantao Station for the year 2009 (January to December) and from the Aru Station (January to June and October to November) are selected.
dataset:
Guantao Station (36°30′54″N, 115°07′39″E) is located in Hezhai Village, Guantao County, Hebei Province. Its observation site and the surrounding underlying surface consist of farmland, including winter wheat, corn, and cotton, with winter wheat and corn being rotated. The growth period for winter wheat is from October to June of the following year, while the growth period for corn is from June to October, and for cotton, it is from May to October. This area represents a typical farmland underlying surface of the North China Plain. In the LAS source area, the area of winter wheat (corn) accounts for about 45%, while cotton accounts for about 47%. 

Arou Station (38°02′40″N, 100°27′53″E) is located in the valley area upstream of the Heihe River, and its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of typical alpine grassland, which is relatively flat. The vegetation height in the source area can reach 0.2 to 0.3 meters during the growing season.
findings: (1) Under unstable conditions, large-scale vortex motion, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scales can significantly affect the applicability of the MOST theory; (2) Two new methods for assessing the applicability of the MOST theory have been established, namely factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, and it has been verified that these two assessment methods are reasonable and reliable.

Example.Question: Provide an example of how aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is calculated using data from field experiments.
Example.Answer: An example is the Xiaotangshan Experiment conducted in Beijing, China, which used an analytical footprint model to calculate the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over different surfaces. This involved using characteristic parameters of roughness elements, such as vegetation height and leaf area index, and aggregating these with a footprint weighting method to determine z0m for the entire experimental field.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of how the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory is applied in the analysis of data from large aperture scintillometers (LAS)?
Example.Answer: An example is the use of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory in analyzing LAS data collected from Guantao Station in 2009. The study examined the applicability of the theory by correlating atmospheric refractive index structure parameters with meteorological data to derive regional average sensible heat fluxes, verifying the theory's applicability under various conditions.

Definition.Question: What does 'aerodynamic roughness length (z0m)' mean in the context of surface flux estimations?
Definition.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations, defined as the height where the wind speed, extrapolated from a logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. It varies widely over different surfaces and is traditionally calculated using wind profile measurements based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory.

Definition.Question: What is the 'Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory' and how is it applied in meteorological observations?
Definition.Answer: The Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) is a framework used for scaling turbulence in the atmospheric boundary layer. It relates the profiles of mean wind speed and temperature to turbulence characteristics and is applied in meteorological observations to derive parameters like the temperature structure parameter and regional average sensible heat flux, as used in studies involving Large Aperture Scintillometers (LAS).

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy-covariance system' mean in the context of surface flux measurement methods?
Definition.Answer: The eddy-covariance system is a recognized method for observing surface fluxes, providing reliable measurements by capturing the covariance between vertical wind speed and scalar quantities (like temperature or humidity) at a high frequency. Though highly accurate, its spatial representativeness is limited to areas of tens to hundreds of meters.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in challenges faced when applying the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory in data collection at 馆陶站 and 阿柔站 compared to using it for estimating surface fluxes in the context of LAS and EC systems?
Comparison.Answer: Both 馆陶站 and 阿柔站 face challenges related to the assumptions of homogeneity required by the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, affected by factors like surface cover and weather conditions. However, while LAS and EC systems at these stations require compatibility with satellite pixel scales, the challenges at 馆陶站 and 阿柔站 focus more on the applicability of the theory under different atmospheric stability conditions and the development of new applicability judgment methods.

Interpretation.Question: What implications does the variability in aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) have for remote sensing algorithms and land surface models, particularly in heterogeneous environments?
Interpretation.Answer: Variability in z0m affects the accuracy of remote sensing algorithms and land surface models because it influences the calculation of surface fluxes. In heterogeneous environments, where z0m varies with vegetation and surface characteristics, models must account for directional dependencies and integrate spatial variability to improve accuracy. This is demonstrated in the Xiaotangshan data, where z0m's directional characteristics are linked to roughness element distribution.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in obtaining aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) for local or regional scales using station observations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: It is difficult to obtain aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) for local or regional scales from station observations because wind turbulence is influenced by the structure and spacing of roughness elements on the land surface. The variation range of z0m is large due to different surfaces, and traditional methods require wind profile measurements, which may not be feasible for larger scales.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the difficulty in extending the spatial representativeness of Eddy-Covariance system measurements beyond small scales?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The Eddy-Covariance system, while reliable for surface flux observations, has a limited spatial representativeness of only a few dozen to a few hundred meters. This is because its measurements are designed for smaller, more localized areas, making it challenging to extend to larger regional scales, which is why alternatives like Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) are considered for broader applications.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of implementing automated meteorological stations with a high-frequency data collection method in agricultural areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing automated meteorological stations with high-frequency data collection, such as every 10 seconds, can lead to more accurate and granular datasets that reflect real-time changes in meteorological conditions. This can improve the understanding of microclimate variations in agricultural areas, aid in precise agricultural management, and enhance the accuracy of weather models and forecasts.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory in analyzing data from large aperture scintillometers in terms of data accuracy and model validation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory for analyzing data from large aperture scintillometers can provide regional scale estimates of sensible heat fluxes, which are crucial for model validation and optimization. However, its applicability can be limited by assumptions of horizontal homogeneity, and factors like large-scale eddy motions and atmospheric turbulence can impact its accuracy, necessitating the development of new assessment methods for its applicability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed to ensure the quality and accuracy of data collected from automatic weather stations in agricultural areas?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collected from automatic weather stations are processed and quality controlled by ensuring a fixed number of data points per day, marking missing data with a specific placeholder, removing duplicate records, and deleting data that fall outside the physical or instrumental range. The date and time are also standardized for consistency.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What is the procedure for using Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) data to analyze the applicability of Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in different land cover conditions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Before analyzing LAS data for MOST theory applicability, preliminary processing of LAS, EC, and AWS data is conducted. The analysis involves selecting relevant LAS data and considering factors such as atmospheric turbulence and temperature scale under unstable conditions. New methods like factor analysis and temperature structure parameter analysis are used to establish and verify the applicability of MOST theory.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the accurate measurement of soil temperature and moisture at various depths in agricultural fields?
Enablement.Answer: The methodologies include the use of soil temperature probes and soil moisture sensors placed at different depths ranging from 0cm to 100cm, as described in the observation data collection methods.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) enable the estimation of surface fluxes over agricultural landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of MOST with atmospheric refractive index structure parameter data and related meteorological data allows for the calculation of regional average sensible heat flux, facilitating surface flux estimations over agricultural landscapes.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or technologies enable the reliable operation of automatic weather stations for continuous data collection over multiple years?
Enablement.Answer: The use of automatic weather stations with sensors for air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, pressure, rainfall, radiation, and soil parameters, along with a data processing and quality control system, enables reliable continuous data collection over multiple years.

Expectation.Question: Why is it challenging to apply Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in certain observational environments, and what data collection techniques could enhance its applicability?
Expectation.Answer: The applicability of MOST is influenced by factors such as surface coverage type, flatness, water-heat conditions, and weather. The use of Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) and Eddy-Covariance system (EC) data, as well as the establishment of new methods like factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, can enhance the applicability of MOST by providing reliable assessments of turbulence and temperature structure.

Expectation.Question: What are the potential challenges of using remote sensing models to estimate aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over various surfaces, and how can datasets be improved to address these challenges?
Expectation.Answer: Remote sensing models face challenges in estimating z0m due to the difficulty in obtaining z0m for local or regional scales from station observations alone. The use of parameterizations that relate z0m to roughness element characteristics like vegetation height and leaf area index, as well as employing datasets that integrate footprint weighting methods, can improve the accuracy and applicability of these models.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways might the data collection frequency and coverage at the automatic weather station impact the accuracy and reliability of meteorological observations?
Judgmental.Answer: The automatic weather station collects data every 10 seconds and outputs it every 10 minutes, which provides a robust dataset for capturing dynamic meteorological changes. However, any missing data is marked with -6999, which could affect data continuity and reliability. The station's thorough data processing and quality control – including removing duplicate records and out-of-range data – aim to enhance accuracy. Yet, ensuring that data collection is consistent and representative across all relevant meteorological conditions remains crucial for reliability.

Judgmental.Question: What are the implications of using different scales of observation instruments, such as the Eddy-Covariance system and Large Aperture Scintillometer, for surface flux measurements?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of instruments like the Eddy-Covariance system, which is internationally recognized for its reliability but limited to smaller spatial scales, contrasts with the Large Aperture Scintillometer, which can capture regional scale fluxes. The latter's ability to match better with satellite pixel scales and model grid scales makes it valuable for remote sensing estimations and model validations. However, ensuring the accuracy of flux measurements across these different scales remains a challenge, particularly when applying theoretical models like the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how data from large aperture scintillometers can be processed to align with satellite pixel scales.
Assertion.Answer: Large Aperture Scintillometers (LAS) provide regional scale average sensible heat flux, which matches well with satellite pixel scales. This is because LAS data is based on Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, which involves measuring atmospheric refractive index structure parameters and meteorological data, allowing for scaling to the spatial grid of satellite models.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the challenges faced in ensuring data quality and consistency in multi-year meteorological observations.
Assertion.Answer: Data quality and consistency challenges in multi-year meteorological observations include ensuring the completeness of data (e.g., 144 data points daily), removing duplicate records, and filtering out values that exceed physical or instrumental limits. Consistent formatting of date and time is also crucial, alongside using standard procedures for data processing and quality control as outlined in the references such as Liu et al. (2013).

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the data collection methods used for observing aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) and suggest potential improvements or alternative methodologies.
Request/Directive.Answer: The traditional method for calculating aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements. In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, obtaining z0m for a local or regional scale using only station observations is challenging. Researchers have suggested parameterizations between aerodynamic roughness length and land surface properties. Using experimental data and analytical footprint models, z0m over different surfaces can be calculated and related to roughness element characteristics. Improvements could involve more comprehensive data collection over various surfaces and conditions, or the development of higher-resolution remote sensing techniques.
